awd_titl_txt: Engaging Secondary Female Students in Ubiquitous Intelligence and Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
The underrepresentation of female students in computing and engineering fields can be attributed to different factors such as gender stereotypes or unfamiliarity with computing and engineering fields. This project will occur in a region in which many secondary female students have not had opportunities to take STEM and Information and Communication Technologies courses. The project aims to broaden the participation of secondary female students in STEM and Information and Communication Technologies fields by engaging them in ubiquitous intelligence and computing. The researchers will engage secondary female students through a five-week summer camp and STEM competition to work on smart city-related projects and applications such as smart citizen services, intelligent transportation system and intelligent energy planning. The project is expected to increase secondary female students’ knowledge, skills, and interests in STEM careers and contribute to the research on female students’ self-concept construction and motivations for learning STEM. 

The major objectives of the project are to: 1) enhance secondary female students’ academic self-concepts in computing and engineering fields through a constructivist learning environment; 2) enhance secondary female students’ knowledge, skills, and interests in these fields; 3) increase the number of secondary female students participating in STEM competitions; and 4) investigate the factors that influence female students’ career choices in STEM and Information and Communication Technologies fields. The project will involve 120 female students from Grades 6-11 in a five-week summer camp to learn Python and Arduino programming.  They will then integrate these tools to develop ubiquitous intelligent systems in tiered teams co-mentored by college students and STEM teachers. In each year, a one-week mentor training workshop will be held to train the mentors, and a two-day Fall STEM Competition Workshop will be organized to promote STEM teachers to organize teams to participate in STEM competitions.  A virtual learning cloud will be used to engage the students and mentors in building the learning community during and after the summer camp. A combination of quantitative and qualitative research methods including surveys, interviews,  and analysis of student artifacts will be used to assess the impact of the project activities on secondary female students’ knowledge, skills, and interests in STEM fields and career choices. 

This project is funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
UNLV ITEST Final Outcome Report

This ITEST project was funded for three years with an additional one year and nine months with no-cost extension. Its primary objectives were to enhance girls’ self-concept, interests, knowledge, and skills in computing and engineering while exploring the benefits of a constructivist learning environment in secondary STEM education.

Key activities in each year included:

  1. A one-week Mentor Training (MT) Workshop to prepare mentors, comprising CCSD middle and high school STEM teachers and college students.
  2. A five-week Girls Understanding Innovation and Computing (GUIC) Summer Camp for engaging 40 female students in Grades 6-11 in learning Arduino & IoT and Robotics Design. Group activities, lab tours, and engineering seminars are also organized.
  3. A two-day STEM Competition Workshop to encourage participants to form teams and engage in STEM competitions.

From 2021 to 2023, the GUIC Summer Camp trained a total of 122 secondary female students, 45% of whom were from underrepresented minority groups. Additionally, 22 STEM teacher mentors and 27 college student mentors participated in the Mentor Training Workshop, while 22 STEM teachers and 19 students attended the STEM Competition Workshop. With support from the IEEE Las Vegas Chapter, Cox, and this ITEST grant, the program funded 27 teams from 23 schools with seed grants to aid their participation in STEM competitions.

Both quantitative and qualitative data collected during the project cycle demonstrated that the ITEST project effectively enhanced participants' academic self-concept and confidence in computing and engineering. Approximately 80% of camp attendees reported that the program improved their academic confidence in these fields and helped them envision a future career in computer science, engineering, or related disciplines. Over the years, the program showed continuous improvement, with around 90% of participants reporting enhanced STEM knowledge and skills. More than 80% enjoyed the hands-on projects and actively sought additional learning resources beyond the camp. Data collected in Year 3 indicated that the project increased students' likelihood of participating in STEM competitions and positively influenced their intent to pursue STEM majors. Approximately 70% of participants agreed that the engineering projects and overall camp experience heightened their interest in studying STEM subjects.

Findings suggest that the most effective components of the program were hands-on labs, project-based learning, and the tiered team structure, all of which were designed based on constructivist learning theory. The tiered team structure facilitated peer mentoring, allowing more experienced students to guide and support other team members. This approach fostered collaboration, increased engagement, and reinforced STEM learning.

 

Participation in the ITEST project during the five-week summer camp yielded significant positive outcomes for secondary school girls from multiple perspectives, including:

 

  1. Enhanced content knowledge in STEM fields through engaging, hands-on learning experiences.
  2. Strengthened recognition of the importance of science and engineering in real-world applications.
  3. Increased enthusiasm and engagement in STEM learning and extracurricular activities.

 

Overall, the ITEST project successfully fostered a stronger STEM identity among female students, equipping them with the confidence and skills necessary to pursue future opportunities in computing and engineering.

 

 

Additional outcomes of the project include:

4. STEM teachers from CCSD who participated as camp mentors experienced the constructivist STEM learning environment firsthand and gained practical knowledge on applying the same approach in their school STEM classes.

5. The activities and learning structure used in the project can be easily replicated in local school districts, paving the way for long-term, sustainable changes in STEM education and engagement.

7. The project prepared students and teachers for continued participation in STEM activities. Learning programming, basics of Arduino & IoT, and basics of robotics in the camp effectively equipped the girls for similar tasks in STEM competitions. Additionally, teachers and students received key guidance on STEM competitions in Nevada and available funding resources.

8. The gained knowledge, strengthened interest, and increased career likelihood in STEM have long-term impacts on girls’ learning and occupational development. All camp participants were girls, with about 45% from underrepresented minorities. The positive outcomes and impacts of the ITEST project are expected to encourage and prepare more girls and students from underrepresented backgrounds to study STEM/ICT majors, fostering greater diversity in STEM fields in the long run.

9. An additional innovative component of the project was integrating an arts component, including poetry, essay and zine writing, crocheting, origami, and crafts, into the STEM-focused summer camp. This STEAM learning environment fostered a sense of belonging and opened more avenues for self-identity development.

10. The project generated valuable academic contributions, including two journal papers and seven conference papers. Additionally, the course syllabi for Introduction to Arduino & IoT and Introduction to Vex V5 Robotics Programming, along with nine project lesson plans, were shared on the project website at https://nsil.sites.unlv.edu/Training.html. Four project videos were also made available on the UNLV ITEST YouTube channel.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/07/2025
Modified by: Mei Yang

UNLV ITEST Final Outcome Report


This ITEST project was funded for three years with an additional one year and nine months with no-cost extension. Its primary objectives were to enhance girls self-concept, interests, knowledge, and skills in computing and engineering while exploring the benefits of a constructivist learning environment in secondary STEM education.


Key activities in each year included:

A one-week Mentor Training (MT) Workshop      to prepare mentors, comprising CCSD middle and high school STEM teachers      and college students.
A five-week Girls Understanding      Innovation and Computing (GUIC) Summer Camp for engaging 40 female students in Grades 6-11 in learning      Arduino & IoT and Robotics Design. Group activities, lab tours, and engineering      seminars are also organized. 
A two-day STEM Competition Workshop to      encourage participants to form teams and engage in STEM competitions.



From 2021 to 2023, the GUIC Summer Camp trained a total of 122 secondary female students, 45% of whom were from underrepresented minority groups. Approximately 80% of camp attendees reported that the program improved their academic confidence in these fields and helped them envision a future career in computer science, engineering, or related disciplines. Data collected in Year 3 indicated that the project increased students' likelihood of participating in STEM competitions and positively influenced their intent to pursue STEM majors. Approximately 70% of participants agreed that the engineering projects and overall camp experience heightened their interest in studying STEM subjects.

The tiered team structure facilitated peer mentoring, allowing more experienced students to guide and support other team members. This approach fostered collaboration, increased engagement, and reinforced STEM learning.





Participation in the ITEST project during the five-week summer camp yielded significant positive outcomes for secondary school girls from multiple perspectives, including:




Enhanced content knowledge in STEM fields      through engaging, hands-on learning experiences.

Overall, the ITEST project successfully fostered a stronger STEM identity among female students, equipping them with the confidence and skills necessary to pursue future opportunities in computing and engineering.








Additional outcomes of the project include:


4. STEM teachers from CCSD who participated      as camp mentors experienced the constructivist STEM learning environment firsthand      and gained practical knowledge on applying the same approach in their      school STEM classes.


5. The activities and learning structure      used in the project can be easily replicated in local school districts,      paving the way for long-term, sustainable changes in STEM education and      engagement.


7. The project prepared students and      teachers for continued participation in STEM activities. Learning      programming, basics of Arduino & IoT, and basics of robotics in the      camp effectively equipped the girls for similar tasks in STEM      competitions. Additionally, teachers and students received key guidance on      STEM competitions in Nevada and available funding resources.


8. The gained knowledge, strengthened      interest, and increased career likelihood in STEM have long-term impacts      on girls learning and occupational development. All camp participants      were girls, with about 45% from underrepresented minorities. The positive      outcomes and impacts of the ITEST project are expected to encourage and      prepare more girls and students from underrepresented backgrounds to study      STEM/ICT majors, fostering greater diversity in STEM fields in the long      run.


9. An additional innovative component of the      project was integrating an arts component, including poetry, essay and      zine writing, crocheting, origami, and crafts, into the STEM-focused      summer camp. This STEAM learning environment fostered a sense of belonging      and opened more avenues for self-identity development.

Additionally, the course syllabi for Introduction to Arduino & IoT and      Introduction to Vex V5 Robotics Programming, along with nine project      lesson plans, were shared on the project website at https://nsil.sites.unlv.edu/Training.html. Four project videos were also made available on the UNLV ITEST      YouTube channel.
